column4: Not to be an idiot, but I have a question - is banshee a gnome-native program?
I believe it is
not between releases, no.  The exception is the LTS releases (there are Live CDs for 8.04, 8.04.1 and 8.04.2)
- oh man... that's a big problem then...
why, what's your actual problem?

- I have 4 drives in my system. When I boot to 9.04 and manually edit the partitions, I see all 4 drives. In 9.10, I don't. It's very strange. I installed 9.10 and decided to try and addt hem to fstab but that was a disaster - fstab has an issue to be worked out in 9.10 it seems (several other users confirmed the same problem).

- fstab issues can be fixed with a patch later. Okay fine. But what about the live cd? I'd like to be able to not only DETECT my drives but also mount them to the corresponding directories. 9.10 didn't even pick up my 2 250gb drives, and theyre just normal SATA drives.
sudo fdisk -l   <-- that doesn't show them?
- it sure does. That's why I'm so confused...
- I have to do more testing later. Currently Im back on 9.04 and getting my drives to ext4 file systems. But it was very weird....
- thats what I get for installing an OS that (at the time) was 2 hours old :P
It *should* have worked :p  Use a more stable distro if you don't like this sort of thing (Debian)
- why would I want to do something foolish like that? :P

- nothing against debian, but I've tried like 30 different distros and ended up back on Ubuntu each time. Its solid, stable, easy to use, etc. Its just what I get for installing a distro version that was so young.
- Im sure when debian pumps out a new version theyre not 100% problem proof :P
ok, cool, whatever works best for you.  Debian stable is *very* stable though (after all, that is the point)
but that's off-topic isn't it
- we dont wanna get yelled at for being off topic when talking about linux in a linux chat. (I know how that goes in here)
I was OT talking about debian.  Now, where were we with your ubuntu trouble?
- not sure if theres anything that can be trouble-shot now. I'm on 9.04. Figured Id give 9.10 a few weeks before I try it again.

it's the disks not being recognised is it?  That's happened to me in the past when I've changed kernels.  You could try to upgrade from jaunty to karmic directly later on, when it's (hopefully) fixed -- no need for a Cd

- it wouldnt be a problem if I could edit Fstab to mount my drives by UUID. But karmic was just acting very very weird. Having other users confirm the same thing just made me think I jumped the gun too soon. So I'm sticking with 9.04 for a few weeks till I hear 9.10 settles down, at least in the fstab department. Other than that I hear great things about it.
ok, fair enough.  I suppose you've tried editing fstab from a live CD

- I have not tried that. I just decided to bag that idea cause my computer also acts as a file server, so I kinda need it running, and to have fstab giving me a headache when that same fstab (I have it backed up) works on every other known version of ubuntu to man, well....
